title: How will Brexit affect the North East? The Treasury knows but they're not going to tell you
text:
How will Brexit affect the North East? The Treasury has analysed the effect of Brexit on the North East but won’t release the results, Chancellor Philip Hammond has revealed. 
He said experts had produced models showing how different regions would be affected when the UK leaves the European Union. 
But the findings will not be published because they are commercially sensitive, he said. 
Mr Hammond was quizzed by Newcastle North MP Catherine McKinnell , a member of the House of Commons Treasury Committee. British Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond (Image: Getty Images Europe) 
He told her the Treasury was “constantly using” a model it had developed to look at how regions would be affected by Brexit, as well as how different sectors of the economy would benefit or suffer. 
She told him: “You must understand there is a public interest in seeing these assessments and understanding the implications of them.” 
Business leaders in the North East have expressed concern in the past about the effect of leaving the EU without a trade deal, given the importance of exports to the region’s economy, and the potential difficulty some firms could face recruiting staff when freedom of movement comes to an end. 
Managers at carmaker Nissan have said it’s essential to ensure items such as car parts can be transported quickly between the UK and EU. Catherine McKinnell (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) 
Ms McKinnell said: “We at least now know the Government is measuring the potential effects of leaving the EU on different parts of the country. 
“It’s frustrating they’re not prepared to actually share any of these assessments, nor indeed explain how they are going to support those regions that will be most affected by Brexit. Read More The round pound stops being legal tender on Sunday but should the deadline be extended? 
“However, the North East is clearly one of the areas most exposed to the impact of a bad – or no – Brexit deal, and indeed to the impact of the whole process of leaving the EU, given our current trading links with Europe, the substantial amount of European funding we receive and the large rural areas in the region in receipt of agricultural support. 
“For a process that is supposed to be about taking back control, there’s a striking lack of transparency in the Government’s planning for it.’ 
MPs are to debate whether or not there should be a SECOND EU referendum . 
The House of Commons debate, scheduled for December 11, will consider whether there should be a referendum “to give the people of this country the final say on the Brexit deal negotiated by the UK and EU”. Read More No u-turn as Government defends Universal Credit roll out 
A second referendum would be held before Brexit takes place in March 2019. 
In practice, if the public voted against the Brexit deal then it could mean the UK stays in the EU after all. 
The debate is a result of a petition which has been signed by 116,576 people. 
It will provide an opportunity for MPs who feel Brexit should be abandoned to speak up. 
However, some MPs who want the UK to stay in the EU have been reluctant to say so in public so far. 
Liberal Democrats are the only major party in England with a policy of giving people a chance to change their minds about Brexit with a second referendum, Scottish party the SNP have said there could be a case for a second referendum. Like us on Facebook
